body:
#1605 paves the way for a completely refactored UI and this means Neovim is getting close to its first release. I'm opening this issue to draw a line for which tasks must be performed before Neovim becomes beta.
#1605 exposes a new UI API based on the ideas of how Vim GUI is implemented: A custom termcap parser that is fed with data passed to ui_write(which normally simply writes to the screen) and calls UI update functions in ui.c. This scenario is hacky and far from ideal(in essence Nvim is parsing its own output), but it will let us do the migration in smaller steps, especially because #1605 introduces a nice way of testing screen state.

With that said, here's what I have planned for the first release:
- [x] Merge #1605
- [x] Add more screen tests
- [x] Refactor the builtin terminal UI for the new UI architecture. The new TUI is based on [unibilium](https://github.com/mauke/unibilium) and [libtermkey](http://www.leonerd.org.uk/code/libtermkey/)
- [x] Remove term.c, term.h and term_defs.h and replace all calls to out_str that output terminal codes by direct calls to ui.c functions. This will remove the termcap hack introduced in #1605 
- [ ] Add a new implementation of the UI layer based on a GUI toolkit. I still haven't chosen a GUI library so suggestions are welcome as long as the library meets these requirements: 
  - is implemented in pure C
  - is very lightweight, Nvim doesn't need advanced GUI features, just enough to implement a RGB terminal-like grid.
  - is cross platform(windows/unix)
- [x] Implement an alternative way of handling commands that require a terminal(#1496/#1528). Fixed by #2076.
- [ ] Make the necessary changes to build/run on Windows(@equalsraf seems to have done a lot of the work already)

Note that even though libtermkey is incompatible with Windows, we are still going to use it for Neovim. The reason is simple: Windows console is a pain and there's no need to maintain a terminal version  that is windows-compatible because no one will ever use it.

If anyone remembers something critical that should be added to the above list just let me know

comment_data.body:
I really hope to $deity I get the chance to look over a lot of this stuff as it is exciting and quite likely defining for Neovim.

Question: I saw the addition of libunibilium/libticket/libtermkey and am I right in assuming that this is a sort of replacement for parts of curses? Can you tell us shortly how they relate, what their function is and why they're better for our purpose?

Thumbs up for libvterm, from the description it sounds like it's exactly what we need.

> Add a new implementation of the UI layer based on a GUI toolkit. I still haven't chosen a GUI library so suggestions are welcome as long as the library meets these requirements:

Do you mean something like GTK+? I don't really see what that's necessary, it could be supplied by a third party. As for me, I'd like to keep using nvim inside of a terminal.

**EDIT**: I'm really not sure we should be calling it Neovim 1.0 quite so quickly. We all know that the intense internal refactoring has resulted in a lot of bugs, which is entirely normal. The way I see it right now we are in alpha, which makes us very flexible and makes users less angry when we break things, which we do. I'd be in favour of moving into beta territory after the list you presented makes it. But I'm not sure I'd want to marry with the first implementation of some of these things or attach our name to a 1.0 release without knowing damn well we are ready to stick by our guns at the API level and think we can provide a user experience with less bugs/surprises (esp. vis-a-vis vanilla Vim).

@aktau: On the three libraries:
  _libtickit_ is the "main front-end" to the set of terminal libraries; you could consider it similar to the higher-level parts of Curses, having abilities to draw bits of text and lines and so on at places on the screen in various pen attributes, handling keyboard and mouse input, etc etc...
  _libtermkey_ is an "internal" part of libtickit, though I have a medium-term plan to just merge it in to the terminal drivers, eventually removing it as a stand-alone entity.
  _unibilium_ is a terminfo-reading library that libtickit uses for the terminfo driver; when it doesn't recognise that the terminal recognises the "modern" set of xterm-based controls.

Both of termkey and unibilium are just dependencies of libtickit; ideally neovim should only ever be calling libtickit functions directly, though I understand currently it does side-step to a certain degree due to current limitations in the API, which I shall need to address.
Thanks for that exposé @leonerd, that's helpful to wrap my head around it :).

> I still haven't chosen a GUI library so suggestions are welcome as long as the library meets these requirements:
> 
> is very lightweight, Nvim doesn't need advanced GUI features, just enough to implement a RGB terminal-like grid.

Do you mean that `(g?)nvim` will launch a GUI window (unless being embedded, of coarse) or to implement a default (non-terminal) GUI client with? In either case (unless I'm way off), I've worked with SDL in the past and it's great. A very simple, clean API that's neither incredibly high- nor low-level. It supports both software and hardware rendering.

I've also heard good things about Allegro, but never used it myself.

I think SDL is best toolkit for neovim.  It is crossplatform, many information, stabled, easy to use.
- GTK+: Windows support is limited
- Qt, wxWidgets: C++

SDL supports image formats by SDL_image.
We can use images in neovim.

SDL supports TrueType font rendering(FreeType, ClearType, DirectWrite?).

SDL does not support many GUI features.  But it is not necessary.

> Can you tell us shortly how they relate, what their function is and why they're better for our purpose?

Complementing @leonerd's explanation, they are better because they perform some tasks that take a lot of term.c/screen.c:
- Find which byte sequences represent special keys/mouse events(check_termcodes is 1k loc and has this purpose)
- Find which byte sequences should be used to control the terminal(cursor positioning, color attributes, etc)
- Find the most efficient way of mirroring the internal screen state to the terminal

termcap/terminfo are databases that contain entries with this kind of information, and are obtained with `tgetent`.

[This](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/05f8d261fe305741ea99c6da2096d890b1005bf7/src/nvim/screen.c#L7343-L7376) is the kind of thing I want to completely remove. We will simply assume that the UI can do tasks like "scroll rectangle x, x', y, y'" and call the appropriate method. The UI layer should find the most efficient way perform the mirroring.

> I'm really not sure we should be calling it Neovim 1.0 quite so quickly. We all know that the intense internal refactoring has resulted in a lot of bugs, which is entirely normal. The way I see it right now we are in alpha, which makes us very flexible and makes users less angry when we break things, which we do. I'd be in favour of moving into beta territory after the list you presented makes it. But I'm not sure I'd want to marry with the first implementation of some of these things or attach our name to a 1.0 release without knowing damn well we are ready to stick by our guns at the API level and think we can provide a user experience with less bugs/surprises (esp. vis-a-vis vanilla Vim).

Thats what I meant by "frozen", I have updated the issue to be more clear about this

> Do you mean that (g?)nvim will launch a GUI window (unless being embedded, of coarse) or to implement a default (non-terminal) GUI client with

nvim will have its own minimal GUI, and it will be linked into the nvim binary. Both nvim UIs(terminal and graphical) will be connectable to remote instances. Embedding will be possible by implementing [this protocol](https://github.com/tarruda/neovim/blob/abstract-ui-termcap/test/functional/ui/screen.lua)

To @Shougo / @splinterofchaos: SDL seems a good candidate, all we need is font rendering with arbitrary formatting.

@tarruda What's Lua plugins(if_lua) roadmap?

But I want to know about the roadmap and the priority.

I think neovim needs killer plugins by lua like neocomplete.
If the great plugins only works in neovim, people want to use it.
To survive editors war, we need more users.

I think SDL_ttf can do it.  But I don't try SDL_ttf...
+1 for using SDL for the GUI. If you really want to change from ncurses (which seems like a HUGE piece of work), check out [Termbox](https://code.google.com/p/termbox/).

Another possible gui candidate is: https://pwmt.org/projects/girara/
Which is a wrapper around gtk+ and provides a vim like setup (main window, status bar etc.). This makes setting up the main interface very easy (see the following example):
https://pwmt.org/projects/girara/code/

EDIT: added link to example code
Another candidate for the terminal emulator library would be http://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/kmscon/libtsm/.

> @tarruda What's Lua plugins(if_lua) roadmap?
> OK, this feature cannot be implement on first release.
> But I want to know about the roadmap and the priority.
> 
> I think neovim needs killer plugins by lua like neocomplete.
> If the great plugins only works in neovim, people want to use it.
> To survive editors war, we need more users.

A 100% vim compatible if_lua layer may take a some time after the first release. If you want lua plugins via msgpack-rpc, it should be very easy to implement on top of [lua-client](https://github.com/neovim/lua-client), all it needs is connectivity via stdin/stdout. 

Unfortunately I'm short on time so I have to focus on the release. After that I will give some priority to plugins in other languages: I plan to implement a C library(libnvimclient) which can be used with any language that has a C bridge. This library will contain all the complexity of a msgpack-rpc client and will be shared for all languages.

> +1 for using SDL for the GUI. If you really want to change from ncurses (which seems like a HUGE piece of work), check out Termbox.

Nvim doesn't use ncurses, just direct calls to <termios.h> and termcap queries with `tgetent`. I've already considered many options including termbox, but decided for libtickit for these reasons:
- Easy integration with programs that have their own event loop.(Maybe I missed but I couldn't find a way to integrate termbox with another event loop)
- Through libtermkey, libtickit has a unique key parsing scheme that is also backwards compatible: http://www.leonerd.org.uk/hacks/fixterms/ .
- Very clean/intuitive API/implementation. It is easy to hack the source code if necessary.
- Very well documented. Both libtermkey and libtickit have a complete set of manpages

> Another possible gui candidate is: https://pwmt.org/projects/girara/
> Which is a wrapper around gtk+ and provides a vim like setup (main window, status bar etc.)

I want to keep nvim a text-only program, so graphical widgets such as  toolbars/buttons are not going to be part of the GUI. Other rich GUIs can be easily developed by third party projects

Will the GUI code still reside in the same repo as Neovim core. Would implementing it as a stand-alone referencing client benefit those who want to focus on the GUI implementation for creating thirdy-party GUI client. Or in other words, would it be an appropriate time point for decoupling the Neovim core from GUI client components.

After that I will give some priority to plugins in other languages: I plan to implement a C library(libnvimclient) which can be used with any language that has a C bridge. This library will contain all the complexity of a msgpack-rpc client and will be shared for all languages.

It is so good information!  OK, I can wait.  I will develop other plugins.

Just a reminder about [multi-carets feature](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/211), so current architecture will keep this in mind and will have background to support this feature in the future (obvious not the first release).

As for the choice of "UI toolkit" (scarequotes because of the rather simplicistic requirements that forego the widgets UI toolkits provide), why not cairo and supplementary libraries like pango to render text? That would probably involve less complexity than with SDL and be similiarly portable.

Just two additional points:
- I think it would be good to drop all features that you deem obsolete before the first release that will be tested by a wider audience (e.g., the 'ex' mode). This way, there would only be one big cut and afterwards nvim would seem to  move forward, feature-wise. 
- I think it is important to be up-to-date with vim patches (even if that would just mean to find out that most of them don't apply anymore), before the first release. Otherwise people might wonder how sustainable this fork is.

+1 for using SDL for the GUI. 

No knowledge of inner workings, by the way. Although Vim is primairly a text-editor, it enables us to use icons in Vim (as images). Not a great difference, but it will be useful for many plugins, like Syntastic, Nerdtree and any new plugins. The plugins will be received like they're grown-ups, instead hacky ones. If Vim detect there is no GUI running, then there are no icons showed. To illustrate the idea, as example (however, the displayed colorscheme is terrible): 

![multitermdedicatedshotpage](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5211845/5344230/b0a6900a-7f0d-11e4-9a15-f9689fa534f8.jpg)

@ReneFroger First, @tarruda explicitly wrote he does not intend on using graphical widgets, such as inline images. "I want to keep nvim a text-only program, so graphical widgets such as toolbars/buttons are not going to be part of the GUI. Other rich GUIs can be easily developed by third party projects.". Second, that screenshot does not display Vim, it displays Emacs. IIRC GTK Vim does not have that ability either. The only thing looking remotely like that I've seen would be [plugins that use patched fonts with icons](https://github.com/ryanoasis/vim-webdevicons).

> Windows console is a pain now I agree, but what if it becomes bearable in newer versions of windows ? I understand that nvim is dropping really old systems and not supporting them anymore, but windows c'mon.

Windows console UIs are very different from their UNIX counterpart. Maintaining something like that will require considerable effort, and that for something that almost no one will use. The only way Nvim will support a windows console UI is if libtickit adds support without changing the public API.

> The reason is simple: Windows console is a pain and there's no need to maintain a terminal version that is windows-compatible because no one will ever use it.

Actually, I do use the Windows console version somewhat frequently, but let's identify what's actually useful about it:
1. Windows (since Windows 7 at least) actually has some subset of unix "pipe" functionality. I use it to pipe things like `grep foo | vim -`. If this launches the Nvim GUI, that's perfectly fine. 
2. Opening files from the command line. It's also fine for this to launch the GUI, and with Nvim's API we can even focus an existing GUI.
3. It opens in the same position and dimensions of the console window. If we could position the Nvim GUI over the console window, that would avoid the discomfort of launching a new window.

> Thats what I meant by "frozen", I have updated the issue to be more clear about this

@tarruda I'm still confused by the title of this thread. We don't need to be version 1.0 for the "first release". It is totally acceptable for the first release to be a beta. We need 10x more feedback from users and plugin authors before freezing the API. 

> Fix handling of shell commands(#1496/#1528) to work with programs that require a tty

> If anyone remembers something critical that should be added to the above list just let me know

Most of the issues in the [first release milestone](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues?page=1&q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+milestone%3A%22first+release%22) are important, I think.

I cannot say if it will open in the same position/dimensions of the console window(if this is something easy to implement, I don't see why not). Reading data from stdin will also be supported.

> @tarruda I'm still confused by the title of this thread. We don't need to be version 1.0 for the "first release".  It is totally acceptable for the first release to be a beta.

1.0 is just a version name, I don't mind if we call it 0.0.1 or something else..

> We need 10x more feedback from users and plugin authors before freezing the API.

Yes, the API will be constantly improving. But we need to draw a line somewhere in order to make a stable release. By frozen I meant that I will create a separate branch(eg: first-release), stop merging big refactorings, new features or changes that have a high risk of causing breakage, and focus on making this branch stable to make an official release.

> Would it be possible, instead, to suspend or background nvim, to allow the actual terminal to run the interactive program, and then, after the program exists, make some API call to nvim to restore it?

That would be more complicated than simply spawning the program in a tty, especially with the client-server architecture(what to do when many clients are connected?)

> On the topic of Wayland, will the neovim GUI have native Wayland support? Or is that something to consider in the long run, to avoid feature creep?

That will most likely come down to which toolkit is chosen, of which SDL2 currently has experimental wayland support (IIRC it's off by default).

If SDL is okay, so why not a more light-weighted one? what about [glfw](http://glfw.org)?

glfw havn't any draw-operations, maybe combine it with [NanoVG](https://github.com/memononen/nanovg) is a choice.

they together smaller than SDL, and give a very good looking.
I both have a lua-glfw and lua-nanovg binding, if need I could public it out.

> Actually, I do use the Windows console version somewhat frequently, but let's identify what's actually useful about it:

But if neovim (or neovim plugins) integrate with command line tools like Conque-shell, you don't have to use console Vim.

I don't know Windows but I would hope it to be easily possible for someone to write a Windows terminal driver for it. Having done that, you'd find you can use all the terminal colours, the aribtrary scrolling regions, the arbitrary modifier key input things; in summary: all the things the Windows console /can/ do that nobody thinks it can do because curses doesn't know about it.

This is not as convenient as using :suspend functionality. Zsh is far less likely to crash due to some plugin or upstream bug then *Vim, so you are guaranteed to have your history with :suspend without any mixings or additional steps (zsh has useful features like SHARE_HISTORY and INC_APPEND_HISTORY, with the latter you have your history in case of crash, but it will be mixed with other shells' history).

I also sometimes relaunch Vim due to e.g. plugin update. Not sure whether SIGHUP handler is able to dump history in zsh (without the aforementioned options enabled) or whatever your favourite shell is. Pretty sure cmd.exe does not bother (does it keep history at all?), dunno about PowerShell.

I am hoping such changes as dropping :suspend or terminal version altogether will not touch *nix terminal version.

> When you do circle back to discuss versioning

This is covered by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/862. 

FYI, the version reported by `:version` is structured according to http://semver.org:

```
0.0.0-alpha+201412081823
^ ^ ^ ^     ^
| | | |      `build metadata
| | | `pre-release
| | `patch
| `minor
`major
```

> I am hoping such changes as dropping :suspend or terminal version altogether will not touch *nix terminal version.

Agreed.

> I am hoping such changes as dropping :suspend or terminal version altogether will not touch *nix terminal version.

Indeed. I really like (love) my terminal version and all the advantages it provides. Even with a radically refactored UI layer, I still believe a terminal version should be a first class citizen with no setbacks vis-a-vis vanilla. Said another way, I'd be sad to see it go.

Pango ("a library for laying out and rendering of text, with an emphasis on internationalization") sounds quite interesting. I've seen that there is an SDL_Pango library, but I have no clue whether SDL, Cairo or something else would be the most appropriate UI library for nvim.

+1 for pango (says the author of pangoterm... ;) )

@fwalch Yes, using Pango would make sure the trickier parts of Vim's text handling (like, Hebrew/Farsi which require proper right-to-left rendering) work out right.
